articles.title: Things People Get Wrong About Electron
articles.description: A long-time maintainer of the wildly successful Electron cross-platform app framework stands by the technical choices Electron has made over the years and defends it against some of the more common criticisms here.
articles.author: Felix Rieseberg

articles.title: Standard Schema: A Common Interface to Schema / Validation Libraries
articles.description: From the creators of Zod, Valibot and ArkType comes a fantastic bit of collaboration to define a common interface to use JavaScript and TypeScript schema libraries.
articles.author: McDonnell, Hiller, and Blass

articles.title: A WebAssembly Compiler That Fits in a Tweet
articles.description: Or 192 bytes, if you prefer. This is a look into a fantastic little bit of JavaScript hacking that can compile arithmetic expressions into WebAssembly you can run very easily. You can learn a lot in so little time here.
articles.author: Mariano Guerra and Patrick Dubroy

articles.title: Announcing TypeScript 5.8 Beta
articles.description: It’s that time again. What’s new? Support for using require() for ES modules in Node 22+, checked returns for conditional and indexed access types, startup and building optimizations & more. While not a huge release overall, it's particularly good for Node devs.
articles.author: Daniel Rosenwasser

articles.title: The Modern Way to Write JavaScript Servers
articles.description: The irony is that while Node popularized JavaScript on the server (though Netscape was doing it in the 90s) this modern, standardized cross-runtime approach doesn’t work on Node ...yet ;-)
articles.author: Marvin Hagemeister

articles.title: Introducing Mentoss: The fetch Mocker
articles.description: A new approach to mocking global fetch() calls (in both browsers and server-side runtimes) inspired by previous attempts like Nock and MSW.
articles.author: Nicholas C. Zakas

articles.title: Lessons from Scaling WebSockets for a JavaScript App
articles.description: Scaling WebSockets for real-time apps presents hidden complexities. Compose shares some lessons learnt the hard way.
articles.author: Atul Jalan

articles.title: docxtemplater: Generate docx and pptx Documents from Templates
articles.description: Generate Word and PowerPoint files dynamically by merging against templates (ideal for invoices, contracts, certificates, etc.) It’s open source (MIT or GPLv3), but the creator has a commercial version with more extensions (e.g. to work with Excel). GitHub repo and feature demos.
articles.author: Edgar Hipp

articles.title: 📊 Plotly 3.0: A JavaScript Graphing Library
articles.description: A high-level, declarative charting library, built on top of D3 and stack.gl, with over 40 chart types, including 3D charts, statistical graphs, and SVG maps. v3 is largely to remove deprecations, fix bugs, and a switch to esbuild.
articles.author: Plotly, Inc.

articles.title: Emittery 1.1: A Simple, Modern Async Event Emitter
articles.description: A small, async event emitter for Node and the browser, and now with support for AbortController.
articles.author: Sindre Sorhus

articles.title: jsontr.ee: Visualize JSON Structures as Dynamic SVG Diagrams
articles.description: You can try it out on this playground, which provides the option to download the diagram as PNG, or use it in an app with customizable styles.
articles.author: Lou Alcalá

articles.title: DBOS Transact v2: Lightweight Durable Execution in TypeScript
articles.description: Durable execution means persisting the execution state of your program while it runs, so if it’s interrupted or crashes, it resumes from where it left off – ideal for long-running or business-critical workflows. Docs.
articles.author: DBOS, Inc.

articles.title: jscanify 1.3: JavaScript Document Scanning Library
articles.description: Given raw photos of documents, this can do paper detection (along with glare suppression), distortion correction, highlighting and extracting. See some visual examples or try it out here.
articles.author: ColonelParrot

articles.title: Ruck 9.0: A React Webapp Framework for Deno
articles.description: A lean React-based way to build modern React apps with Deno using features like ESM, dynamic imports, HTTP imports, and import maps with no transpilation or bundling.
articles.author: Jayden Seric

articles.description: 🎬 Remember Honeypot's well-received Node.js documentary? (If not, watch it!) Now there's a trailer for an Angular documentary due soon.

There's been a lot of chatter about Create React App being effectively 'deprecated' due to a lack of updates from Meta. Turns out, it is deprecated, but the process is now being managed gracefully and some basic React 19 support will be merged in.
A developer came up with an approach to making npm packages 5% smaller using Zopfli compression and asked the npm team to consider it. Ultimately the decision was no for a variety of reasons.
⭐ The Syntax YouTube channel presents ▶️ a fun countdown of the top 15 most starred JavaScript projects on GitHub. This is so well put together.
Astro 5.2 – The popular framework adds Tailwind CSS 4 support and more niceties.
pnpm 10.1 – The alternative, efficient package manager.
Prisma 6.3 – Popular ORM for Node.js and TypeScript.
⭐ Phaser v4 Beta 5, Node.js 23.7, npm 11.1, Neutralinojs 5.6

articles.title: Tailwind CSS v4.0
articles.description: An all-new, ground-up rewrite of the highly popular framework. Version 4 arrived just after we hit send last week — it’s “optimized for performance and flexibility”, takes full advantage of modern web platform features, and is now CSS-first, moving away from a JS-based configuration. There’s lot of detail to dig into here.
articles.author: Adam Wathan

articles.title: Interop 2024 Brings More Features to Baseline
articles.description: We recently shared Jen Simmons’ report from the WebKit team on the progress made across the Interop project last year, now it’s the turn of Rachel Andrew of the Chrome team to look “back at the most successful year ever for the project”.
articles.author: Rachel Andrew

articles.title: Revisiting CSS Multi-Column Layout
articles.description: Andy explores the somewhat underused Multi-Column Layout module, looking at its history, limitations, and modern, practical uses. We also see how features like :has() selectors and container queries now make it a rather powerful tool.
articles.author: Andy Clarke

articles.title: Build for the Web, Build on the Web, Build with the Web
articles.description: Harry reminds us to take advantage of the “un-versioned by design” web platform: “What’s brand new today starts to show its age much more quickly than something that’s already stood the test of time”.
articles.author: Harry Roberts

articles.title: Considerations for Making a Tree View Component Accessible
articles.description: A look behind the scenes at GitHub’s attempts to make the tree view on GitHub repos be more accessible. It’s a surprisingly complex thing to get right.
articles.author: Eric Bailey (GitHub)

articles.title: So, You Want to Push a Web Platform Feature?
articles.description: If you’re curious about browser development Yoav shares some advice on why you may want to contribute, and how to go about doing so.
articles.author: Yoav Weiss

articles.title: 🎲 Some Things You Might Not Know About Custom Counter Styles
articles.description: Outlines how @counter-styles opens up new ways of working with lists and list markers.
articles.author: Geoff Graham

articles.title: The Speed Trifecta: 11ty, Brotli 11, and CSS Fingerprinting
articles.description: Matt explores a blended approach to optimizing CSS by combining Brotli compression and CSS fingerprinting, delivering the gains via a custom 11ty shortcode.
articles.author: Matt Hobbs

articles.title: 🤖 Running Inference in Web Extensions
articles.description: Firefox Nightly is shipping with an 'AI runtime' API you can use for offline machine learning tasks in Web extensions. It uses Transformers.js and is already used in Firefox 133 to provide alt text for images in PDFs.
articles.author: Tarek Ziadé (Mozilla)

articles.title: Positioning Text Around Elements with CSS Offset
articles.description: Explores how CSS offset can offer an easy option for adding pleasing text along borders, textual annotations, etc.
articles.author: Preethi Sam

articles.title: Squish: Batch Client-Side Image Compression Powered by Wasm
articles.description: Includes support for AVIF, JPEG, JPEGXL, PNG, and WebP. You can install it locally or try it in the browser here. Allows quality adjustment, batch processing, and real-time preview, among other features.
articles.author: Addy Osmani

articles.title: Unpic 1.0: A Toolkit for Displaying Images on the Web
articles.description: A family of components and libraries for working with images on the Web, whether it’s through components for many different frameworks or working with images hosted on many different providers and CDNs.
articles.author: Matt Kane

articles.title: Prompts: A Lightweight Async Alternative to alert(), prompt(), and confirm()
articles.description: Includes some basic styling for the prompts, which are like modals, and they’re designed to be keyboard-friendly and based on JS Promises.
articles.author: Simon Willison

articles.title: Blendy: Smoothly Transition One Element Into Another
articles.description: The demo is essentially an animated modal window but there could be other applications for this. It works with any framework and the code is simply a few lines defining the source and target elements.
articles.author: Taha Shashtari
